title: 115_hr1582
content:
The "Duty First Act" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings as outlined in Section 2. The 1st Infantry Division, established in 1917, is the oldest combat division of the US Army. It has served continuously and fought in major conflicts, except the Korean War. In World War I, it was the first US division in France, achieving the first American victory at the Battle of Cantigny in 1918. The 1st Infantry Division, the oldest combat division of the US Army, fought in major conflicts and played pivotal roles in World War I and World War II. It received the Medal of Honor in WWI and was the lead assault division on Omaha beach in Normandy on D-Day in WWII. The 1st Infantry Division played key roles in liberating France and Belgium, the Battle of the Bulge, crossing the Rhine River, and defeating Nazi Germany. It supported the International War Crimes Tribunal in Nuremberg after the war. Seventeen soldiers received the Medal of Honor in WWII. The division was the only US combat division in Europe from 1946 to 1951 before returning to the US in 1955. In 1965, it was one of the first two combat divisions deployed to Vietnam, defending the Highway 13 corridor against enemy infiltration. The 1st Infantry Division played key roles in WWII, with 17 soldiers receiving the Medal of Honor. In Vietnam, it fought in Operation Junction City in 1967 and all 3 waves of the Tet Offensive in 1968. The division deterred Soviet aggression in Europe from 1970 to 1990 and deployed to Saudi Arabia in 1991 for Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm. The 1st Infantry Division enforced peace agreements in Bosnia, Macedonia, and Kosovo. It deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan multiple times between 2003 and 2014. The division provided military assistance in Africa and deployed to combat ISIS in Iraq and Kuwait. The 1st Infantry Division has been deployed to Iraq, Afghanistan, and Korea in 2016 and 2017. It has earned several unit decorations and served the United States with valor and distinction since its organization. The 1st Infantry Division has served with valor and distinction since its organization, embodying its motto "No mission too difficult, no sacrifice too great--Duty First". SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATION. The Secretary of Treasury shall mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions as outlined in the Act. The coins minted under this Act shall be legal tender and considered numismatic items, minted to specific specifications for half dollar coins. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the 100 year anniversary of the 1st Infantry Division, with specific inscriptions and designations required. The design will be chosen by the secretary in consultation with relevant organizations and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the West Point Mint within a 1-year period starting in January 2018.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before issuance. All sales of coins issued under this Act include surcharges of $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $5 for the half-dollar coin. Surcharges received will be promptly paid to the Society of the 1st Infantry Division for memorial renovation. The society will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge may be included for the issuance of any coin under this Act. The issuance of any coin under this Act must not exceed the annual commemorative coin program limit. The Secretary of the Treasury can provide guidance for this.
